To aime at other obiects: which if miss'd,
Their enui's like an arrow, shot vpright,
That, in the fall, indangers their owne heads.
WHat, CRITES! where haue you drawne forth the day?
You haue not visited your jealous friends?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Where I haue seene (most honour'd ARETE,)
The strangest pageant, fashion'd like a court,
(At least I dream't I saw it) so diffus'd,
So painted, pyed, and full of rainbow straines,
As neuer yet (eyther by time, or place)
Was made the food to my distasted sence:
Nor can my weake imperfect memorie
Now render halfe the formes vnto my tongue,
That were conuolu'd within this thriftie roome.
Here, stalkes me by a proud, and spangled sir,
That lookes three hand-fuls higher then his fore-top;
Sauours himselfe alone, is onely kind
And louing to himselfe: one that will speake
More darke, and doubtfull then six oracles;
Salutes a friend, as if he had a stitch,
Is his owne chronicle, and scarce can eat
For registring himselfe: is waited on
By mimiques, jesters, pandars, parasites,
And other such like prodigies of men.
He past, appeares some mincing marmoset
Made all of clothes, and face; his limbes so set
As if they had some voluntarie act
Without mans motion, and must mooue iust so
In spite of their creation: one that weighes
His breath betweene his teeth, and dares not smile
Beyond a point, for feare t'vnstarch his looke;
Hath trauell'd to make legs, and seene the cringe
Of seuerall courts, and courtiers; knowes the time
Of giuing titles, and of taking wals;
Hath read court-common-places; made them his:
Studied the grammar of state, and all the rules
Each formall vsher in that politike schoole,
Can teach a man. A third comes giuing nods
To his repenting creditors, protests
To weeping sutors, takes the comming gold
Of insolent, and base ambition,
That hourely rubs his dry, and itchie palmes:
Which grip't, like burning coales, he hurles away
Into the laps of bawdes, and buffons mouthes.
With him there meets some subtle PROTEVS, one
Can change, and varie with all formes he sees;
Be any thing but honest; serues the time;
Houers betwixt two factions, and explores
The drifts of both; which (with crosse face) he beares
To the diuided heads, and is receiu'd
With mutuall grace of eyther: one that dares
Doe deeds worthie the hurdle, or the wheele,
To be thought some bodie; and is (in sooth)
Such as the Satyrist points truly forth,
That onely to his crimes owes all his worth.

sp.speaker: ARE.
sp.l: You tell vs wonders, CRITES.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: This is nothing.
There stands a Neophyte glazing of his face,
Pruning his clothes, perfuming of his haire,
Against his idoll enters; and repeates
(Like an vnperfect prologue, at third musike)
His part of speeches, and confederate iests,
In passion to himselfe. Another sweares
His Scene of courtship ouer; bids, beleeue him,
Twentie times, ere they will; anon, doth seeme
As he would kisse away his hand in kindnesse;
Then walkes of melancholike, and stands wreath'd,
As he were pinn'd vp to the arras, thus.
A third is most in action, swimmes, and friskes,
Playes with his mistresse pappes, salutes her pumps,
Adores her hems, her skirts, her knots, her curles,
Will spend his patrimonie for a garter,
Or the least feather in her bounteous fanne.
A fourth, he onely comes in for a mute:
Diuides the act with a dumbe shew, and exit.
Then must the ladies laugh, straight comes their Scene,
A sixt times worse confusion then the rest.
Where you shall heare one talke of this mans eye;
Another, of his lip; a third, his nose;
A fourth commend his legge; a fift his foot;
A sixt his hand; and euery one a limme:
That you would thinke the poore distorted gallant
Must there expire. Then fall they in discourse
Of tires, and fashions, how they must take place,
Where they may kisse, and whom, when to sit downe,
And with what grace to rise; if they salute,
What curt'sie they must vse: such cob-web stuffe,
As would enforce the common'st sense abhorre
Th' Arachnean workers.

sp.speaker: ARE.
sp.l: Patience, gentle CRITES.
This knot of spiders will be soone dissolu'd,
And all their webs swept out of CYNTHIAS court,
When once her glorious deitie appeares,
And but presents it selfe in her full light:
Till when, goe in, and spend your houres with vs
Your honour'd friends, TIME, and PHRONESIS,
In contemplation of our goddesse name.
Thinke on some sweet, and choice inuention, now,
Worthie her serious, and illustrous eyes,
That from the merit of it we may take
Desir'd occasion to preferre your worth,
And make your seruice knowne to CYNTHIA.
It is the pride of ARETE to grace
Her studious louers; and (in scorne of time,
Enuie, and ignorance) to lift their state
Aboue a vulgar height. True happinesse
Consists not in the multitude of friends,
But in the worth, and choice. Nor would I haue
Vertue a popular regard pursue:
Let them be good that loue me, though but few.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: I kisse thy hands, diuinest ARETE,
And vow my selfe to thee, and CYNTHIA.

sp.p: A Little more forward: So, sir. Now goe in, dis-cloke your selfe, and come forth. Taylor, bestow thy absence vpon vs; and bee not prodigall of this secret, but to a deare customer. 'Tis well entend, sir. Stay, you come on too fast; your pase is too impetuous. Imagine this to be the palace of your pleasure, or place, where your lady is pleas'd to bee seene. First, you present your selfe, thus: and spying her, you fall off, and walke some two turnes; in which time, it is to bee suppos'd, your passion hath sufficiently whited your face: then (stifling a sigh or two, and closing your lips) with a trembling boldnesse, and bold terrour, you aduance your selfe forward. Proue thus much, I pray you.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Yes, sir, (pray IOVE I can light on it) Here, I come in, you say, and present my selfe?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: And then I spie her, and walke off?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Now, sir, I stifle, and aduance forward?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Trembling.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Yes, sir, trembling: I shall doe it better when I come to it. And what must I speake now?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Mary, you shall say: Deare beautie, or, sweet honour (or by what other title you please to remember her) me thinkes you are melancholy. This is, if shee be alone now, and discompanied.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Well, sir, Ile enter againe; her title shall be, My deare LINDABRIDES.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: LINDABRIDES?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I, sir, the Emperour ALICANDROES daughter, and the Prince MERIDIANS sister (in the Knight of the Sunne) shee should haue beene married to him, but that the Princesse CLARIDIANA—

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: O, you betray your reading.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Nay, sir, I haue read historie, I am a little humanitian. Interrupt me not, good sir. My deare LINDABRIDES, My deare LINDABRIDES, My deare LINDABRIDES, me thinkes you are melancholy.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I, and take her by the rosie-finger'd hand.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Must I so? O, my deare LINDABRIDES, mee thinkes you are melancholy.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Or thus, sir. All varietie of diuine pleasures, choice sports, sweet musique, rich fare, braue attire, soft beds, and silken thoughts attend this deare beautie.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Beleeue mee, that's pretty. All varietie of diuine pleasures, choice sports, sweet musique, rich fare, braue attires, soft beds, and silken thoughts, attend this deare beautie.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: And then, offring to kisse her hand, if shee shall coily recoile, and signifie your repulse; you are to re-enforce your selfe, with, More then most faire ladie, let not the rigour of your iust disdaine thus coursly censure of your seruants zeale: and, withall, protest her, to be the onely, and absolute vnparalell'd creature you do adore and admire, and respect, and reuerence, in this court, corner of the world, or kingdome.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: This is hard, by my faith. I'le begin it all, againe.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Doe so, and I will act it for your ladie.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Will you vouchsafe, sir? All varietie of diuine pleasures, choice sports, sweet musique, rich fare, braue attire, soft beds, and silken thoughts attend this deare beautie.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: So, sir, pray you away.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: More then most faire ladie, let not the rigour of your iust disdaine, thus courtly censure of your seruants zeale, I protest, you are the onely, and absolute, vnapparelled—

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Vnparalelld.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Vnparalelld creature, I doe adore, and admire, and respect, and reuerence, in this court, corner of the world, or kingdome.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: This is, if shee abide you. But now, put case shee should bee passant when you enter, as thus: you are to frame your gate thereafter, and call vpon her, Ladie, Nymph, Sweet refuge, Starre of our court. Then if shee be guardant, here: you are to come on, and (laterally disposing your selfe) sweare, by her blushing and well coloured cheeke, the bright die of her haire, her morie teeth (though they be ebonie) or some such white, and innocent oth, to induce you. If reguardant, then maintaine your station, briske, and irpe, shew the supple motion of your pliant bodie, but (in chiefe) of your knee, and hand, which cannot but arride her proud humour exceedingly.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I conceiue you, sir, I shall performe all these things in good time, I doubt not, they doe so hit me.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Well, sir, I am your ladie; make vse of any of these beginnings, or some other out of your owne inuention: and proue, how you can hold vp, and follow it. Say, say.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Yes, sir, my deare LINDABRIDES.—

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: No, you affect that LINDABRIDES too much. And (let mee tell you) it is not so courtly. Your pedant should prouide you some parcells of french, or some pretty commoditie of italian to commence with, if you would be exoticke, and exquisite.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Yes, sir, he was at my lodging t'other morning, I gaue him a doublet.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p:
Double your beneuolence, and giue him the hose too, clothe you his bodie, he will helpe to apparell your mind. But now, see what
your proper GENIVS can performe alone, without adiection of any other MINERVA.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I comprehend you, sir.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I doe stand you, sir: fall backe to your first place. Good, passing well: Very properly pursude.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Beautifull, ambiguous, and sufficient ladie, what! are you all alone?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: We would be, sir, if you would leaue vs.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I am at your beauties appointment, bright angell; but—

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: What but?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: No harme, more then most faire feature.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: That touch relished well.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: But, I protest—

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: And why should you protest?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p:
For good will (deare esteem'd Madam) and I hope, your ladiship will so conceiue of it:
And will, in time, returne from your disdaine,
And rue the suffrance of our friendly paine.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: O, that peece was excellent! if you could picke out more of these play-particles, and (as occasion shall salute you) embroider, or damaske your discourse with them, perswade your soule, it would most iudiciously commend you. Come, this was a well discharg'd, and auspicious bout. Proue the second.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Ladie, I cannot ruffle it in red and yellow.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Why, if you can reuell it in white, sir, 'tis sufficient.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Say you so, sweet ladie? Lan, tede, de, de, de, dant, dant, dant, dante, &c. No (in good faith) Madame, whosoeuer told your ladiship so, abusde you; but I would be glad to meet your ladiship in a measure.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Me, sir? belike you measure me by your selfe, then?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Would I might, faire feature.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: And what were you the better, if you might?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: The better it please you to aske, faire ladie.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Why, this was rauishing, and most acutely continu'd. Well, spend not your humour too much, you haue now competently exercised your conceit: This (once or twice a day) will render you an accomplisht, elaborate, and well leuelled gallant. Conuey in your courting-stock, wee will (in the heat of this) goe visit the Nymphs chamber.
I Would this water would ariue once, our trauailing friend so commended to vs.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: So would I, for hee has left all vs in trauaile with expectation of it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Pray IOVE, I neuer rise from this couch, if euer I thirsted more for a thing, in my whole time of being a courtier.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Nor I, I'le be sworne: The very mention of it sets my lips in a worse heate, then if he had sprinkled them with MERCVRY. Reach me the glasse, sirrah.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Here, ladie.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: They doe not peele, sweet Charge, doe they?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Yes, a little, Guardian.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: O, 'tis an eminent good signe. Euer when my lips doe so, I am sure to haue some delicious good drinke, or other approching.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Mary, and this may be good for vs ladies: for (it seemes) tis far-fet by their stay.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: My palate for yours (deare Honor) it shall proue most elegant, I warrant you: O, I doe fancy this geare that's long a comming, with an unmeasurable straine.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Pray thee sit downe, PHILAVTIA, that rebatu becomes thee singularly.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Is't not queint?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Yes faith. Me thinkes, thy seruant HEDON is nothing so obsequious to thee, as he was wont to be; I know not how, hee's growne out of his garbe a late, hee's warpt.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: In trunesse, and so me thinkes too; hee's much conuerted.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Tut, let him bee what hee will, 'tis an animall I dreame not of. This tire (me thinkes) makes me looke very ingeniously, quick, and spirited, I should be some LAVRA, or some DELIA, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: As I am wise (faire Honors) that title shee gaue him, to bee her Ambition, spoild him: Before, hee was the most propitious and obseruant young nouice—

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: No, no, you are the whole heauen awry, Guardian: 'tis the swaggering coach-horse ANAIDES, drawes with him there, has beene the diuerter of him.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: For CVPIDS sake, speake no more of him; would I might neuer dare to looke in a mirror againe, if I respect ere a marmaset of them al, otherwise, then I would a feather, or my shittle-cock, to make sport with, now and then.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Come, sit downe; troth (and you be good Beauties) let's runne ouer 'hem all now: Which is the properst man amongst them? I say, the trauailer, AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O, fie on him, he lookes like a venetian trumpetter, i' the battaile of Lepanto, in the gallerie yonder; and speakes to the tune of a countrey ladie, that comes euer i' the rereward, or traine of a fashion.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: I should haue iudgement in a feature, sweet Beauties.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: A bodie would thinke so, at these yeeres.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: And I preferre another now, far before him, a million at least.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who might that be, Guardian?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Mary (faire Charge) ANAIDES.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: ANAIDES! you talk't of a tune PHILAVTIA, there's one speakes in a key: like the opening of some Iustices gate, or a poste-boies horne, as if his voice fear'd an arrest for some ill wordes it should giue, and were loth to come forth.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I, and he has a very imperfect face.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Like a sea-monster, that were to rauish ANDROMEDA from the rocke.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: His hand's too great too, by at least a strawes breadth

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Nay, he has a worse fault then that, too.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: A long heele?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: That were a fault in a ladie, rather then him: No, they say, hee puts off the calues of his legs, with his stockings, euery night.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Out vpon him: turne to another of the pictures, for loues sake. What saies ARGVRION? whom doo's shee commend, afore the rest?

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: I hope, I haue instructed her sufficiently for an answere.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Troth, I made the motion to her ladiship for one to day, i' the presence, but it appear'd shee was other-waies furnisht before: Shee would none.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who was that, ARGVRION?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Mary, the poore plaine gentleman, i' the blacke, there.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who, CRITES?

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: I, I, he. A fellow, that no body so much as lookt vpon, or regarded, and shee would haue had me done him particular grace.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: That was a true tricke of your selfe, MORIA, to perswade ARGVRION, to affect the scholer.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Tut, but shee shall be no chuser for me. In good faith, I like the citizens sonne there, ASOTVS, mee thinkes, none of them all come neere him.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Not, HEDON?

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: HEDON, in troth no. HEDON'S a pretty slight courtier, and he weares his clothes well, and sometimes in fashion; Mary, his face is but indifferent, and he has no such excellent body. No, th'other is a most delicate youth, a sweet face, a streight body, a well proportion'd legge and foot, a white hand, a tender voice.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How now, ARGVRION?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O, you should haue let her alone, shee was bestowing a copy of him vpon vs. Such a nose were inough to make me loue a man, now.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And then his seuerall colours he weares; wherein he flourisheth changeably, euery day.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O, but his short haire, and his narrow eyes!

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Why, shee dotes more palpably vpon him, then ere his father did vpon her.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p:
Beleeue mee, the young gentleman deserues it. If shee could dote more, 'twere not amisse. Hee is an exceeding proper youth, and
would haue made a most neate barber-surgeon, if hee had beene put to it in time.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Say you so? me thinkes, he lookes like a taylour alreadie.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I, that had sayed on one of his customers sutes. His face is like a squeezed orange, or—

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Well, ladies, jest on: the best of you both would be glad of such a seruant.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: I, I'le be sworne would they, though hee be a little shame-fac'd.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Shame-fac'd, MORIA! out vpon him. Your shame-fac'd seruant is your onely gull.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Goe to, Beauties, make much of time, and place, and occasion, and opportunitie, and fauourites, and things that belong to 'hem, for I'le ensure you, they will all relinquish; they cannot indure aboue another yeere; I know it out of future experience: and therefore take exhibition, and warning. I was once a reueller my selfe, and though I speak it (as mine owne trumpet) I was then esteem'd—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: The very march-pane of the court, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: And all the gallants came about you like flies, did they not?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Goe to, they did somewhat, that's no matter now.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Nay, good MORIA, be not angrie. Put case, that wee foure now had the grant from IVNO, to wish our selues into what happie estate wee could? what would you wish to be, MORIA?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Who I? Let me see now. I would wish to be a wise woman, and know all the secrets of court, citie, and countrie. I would know what were done behind the arras, what vpon the staires, what i' the garden, what i' the Nymphs chamber, what by barge, & what by coach. I would tel you which courtier were scabbed, and which not; which ladie had her owne face to lie with her a-nights, & which not; who put off their teeth with their clothes in court, who their haire, who their complexion; and in which boxe they put it. There should not a Nymph, or a widdow be got with childe i' the verge, but I would guesse (within one or two,) who was the right father: and in what moneth it was gotten; with what words; and which way. I would tell you, which Madame lou'd a Monsieur, which a player, which a page; who slept with her husband, who with her friend, who with her gentleman-vsher, who with her horse-keeper, who with her monkie, and who with all. Yes, and who jigg'd the cocke too.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Fye, you'ld tell all,

sp.speaker: MORIA.
sp.p: If I should wish now, it should bee to haue your tongue out. But what sayes PHILAVTIA? who would she be?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p:
Troth, the verie same I am. Onely I would wish my selfe a little more command, and soueraignetie; that all the court were subiect to my absolute becke, and all things in it depending on my looke; as if there were no other heauen, but in my smile, nor other hell, but in my frowne; that I might send for any man I list, and haue his head cut off, when I haue done with him; or made an eunuch, if he denyed mee: and if I saw a better
face then mine owne, I might haue my doctor to poyson it. What would you wish, PHANTASTE?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot (readily) tell you what; But (mee thinkes) I should wish my selfe all manner of creatures. Now, I would bee an empresse; and by and by a dutchesse; then a great ladie of state; then one of your miscelany madams; then a waiting-woman; then your cittizens wife; then a course countrey gentlewoman; then a deyrie maide; then a shepheards lasse; then an empresse againe, or the queene of fayries: And thus I would prooue the vicissitudes, and whirle of pleasures, about, and againe. As I were a shepheardesse, I would bee pip'd and sung too; as a deyrie wench, I would dance at may-poles, and make sillabubbes; As a countrey gentlewoman, keep a good house, and come vp to terme, to see motions; As a cittizens wife, bee troubled with a iealous husband, and put to my shifts; (others miseries should bee my pleasures) As a waiting-woman, I would taste my ladies delights to her; As a miscellany madame inuent new tyres, and goe visite courtiers; As a great ladie, lye a bed, and haue courtiers visite mee; As a dutchesse, I would keepe my state: and as an empresse, I'ld doe any thing. And, in all these shapes, I would euer bee follow'd with th' affections of all that see mee. Mary, I my selfe would affect none; or if I did, it should not bee heartily, but so as I might saue my selfe in 'hem still, and take pride in tormenting the poore wretches. Or, (now I thinke on't) I would, for one yeere, wish my selfe one woman, but the richest, fairest, and delicatest in a kingdome, the very center of wealth, and beautie, wherein all lines of loue should meet; and in that person I would prooue all manner of suters, of all humours, and of all complexions, and neuer haue any two of a sort: I would see how Loue (by the power of his object) could worke inwardly alike, in a cholericke man, and a sanguine; in a melancholique, and a phlegmatique; in a foole, and a wise man; in a clowne, and a courtier; in a valiant man, and a coward: and how he could varie outward, by letting this gallant expresse himselfe in dumbe gaze; another with sighing, and rubbing his fingers; a third, with play-ends, and pittifull verses; a fourth, with stabbing himselfe, and drinking healths, or writing languishing letters in his bloud; a fifth, in colour'd ribbands, and good clothes; with this lord to smile, and that lord to court, and the t'other lord to dote, and one lord to hang himselfe. And then, I to haue a booke made of all this, which I would call the booke of humours, and euery night reade a little piece, ere I slept, and laugh at it. Here comes HEDON.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene II.
div.stage: HEDON, ANAIDES, MERCVRIE, PHANTASTE, PHILAVTIA, MORIA, ARGVRION, CVPID.

sp.p: SAue you, sweet and cleere beauties: By the spirit that moues in me, you are all most pleasingly bestow'd, ladies. Onely, I can take it for no good omen, to find mine Honor so deiected.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: You need not feare, sir, I did of purpose humble my selfe against your comming, to decline the pride of my ambition.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Faire Honor, Ambition dares not stoope; but if it be your sweet pleasure, I shall lose that title, I will (as I am HEDON) apply my selfe to your bounties.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: That were the next way to distitle my selfe of honor. O, no, rather be still ambitious, I pray you.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: I will be any thing that you please, whilst it pleaseth you to bee your selfe, ladie. Sweet PHANTASTE, deare MORIA, most beautifull ARGVRION—

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Farewell, HEDON.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: ANAIDES, stay, whither goe you?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: S'light, what should I doe here? and you engrosse 'hem all for your owne vse, 'tis time for me to seeke out.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: I, engrosse 'hem? Away, mischiefe, this is one of your extrauagantiests now, because I began to salute 'hem by their names—

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Faith, you might haue sparde vs Madame Prudence, the Guardian there, though you had more couetously aym'd at the rest.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: S'heart, take 'hem all, man: what speake you to me of ayming, or couetous?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: I, say you so? nay, then, haue at 'hem: ladies, here's one hath distinguish'd you by your names alreadie. It shall onely become me, to aske, How you doe?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Gods so, was this the designe you trauaill'd with?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who answeres the brazen head? it spoke to some bodie.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Lady Wisedome, doe you interpret for these puppets?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: In truth, and sadnesse (Honors) you are in great offence for this, goe too: the gentleman (I'le vnder-take with him) is a man of faire liuing, and able to maintaine a ladie in her two carroches a day, besides pages, munkeys, and parachitos, with such attendants as shee shall thinke meet for her turne, and therefore there is more respect requirable, howsoere you seeme to conniue. Harke you, sir, let mee discourse a sillable with you. I am to say to you, these ladies are not of that close, and open behauiour, as happily you may suspend; their carriage is well knowne, to be such as it should be, both gentle and extraordinarie.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: O, here comes the other paire.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene III.
div.stage: AMORPHVS, ASOTVS, HEDON, ANAIDES, MERCVRIE, CVPID, PHANTASTE, PHILAVTIA, ARGVRION, MORIA.

sp.p: THat was your fathers loue, the Nymph ARGVRION. I would haue you direct all your courtship thither, if you could but endeare your selfe to her affection, you were eternally en-gallanted.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: In truth, sir? pray PHOEBVS I proue fauour-some in her faire eyes.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: All diuine mixture, and increase of beautie to this bright beuy of ladies; and to the male-courtiers, complement, and courtesie.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: In the behalfe of the males, I gratifie you, AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: And I, of the females.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Succinctly return'd. I doe vale to both your thankes, and kisse them: but primarily to yours, most ingenious, acute, and polite ladie.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Gods my life, how hee doe's all to beequalifie her! ingenious, acute, and polite? as if there were not others in place as ingenious, acute, and polite, as shee.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Yes, but you must know, ladie, hee cannot speake out of a dictionarie method.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Sit downe, sweet AMORPHVS: When will this water come, thinke you?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: It cannot now be long, faire ladie.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Now obserue, MERCVRY.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: How? most ambiguous beautie? loue you? that I will by this hand-kercher.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: S'lid, he drawes his othes out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: But, will you be constant?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Constant, Madam? I will not say for constantnesse, but by this purse (which I would be loth to sweare by, vnlesse 'twere embroider'd) I protest (more then most faire ladie) you are the onely, absolute, and vnparalelld creature, I doe adore, and admire, and respect, and reuerence in this court, corner of the world, or kingdome: Mee thinkes you are melancholy.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Do's your heart speake all this?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Say you?—

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: O, he is groping for another oth.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Now, by this watch (I made how forward the day is) I doe vnfeignedly vow my selfe (s'light 'tis deeper then I tooke it, past fiue) yours entirely addicted, Madame.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: I require no more, dearest ASOTVS, hence-forth let mee call you mine, and in remembrance of me, vouchsafe to weare this chaine, and this diamond.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: O god, sweet ladie!

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: There are new othes for him: what? doth HERMES taste no alteration, in all this?

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Yes, thou hast strooke ARGVRION inamour'd on ASOTVS, the thinkes.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Alas, no; I am no-body, I: I can doe nothing in this disguise.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: But thou hast not wounded any of the rest, CVPID?

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Not yet: it is enough that I haue begun so prosperously.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Nay, these are nothing to the gems I will hourely bestow vpon thee: be but faithfull, and kind to me, and I will lade thee with my richest bounties: behold, here my bracelets, from mine armes.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Not so, good ladie, By this diamond.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Take 'hem, weare 'hem: my iewels, chaine of pearle, pendants, all I haue.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Nay then, by this pearle, you make me a wanton.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Shall not shee answere for this, to maintayne him thus in swearing?

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: O, no, there is a way to weane him from this, the gentleman may be reclaim'd.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: I, if you had the ayring of his apparell, couss', I thinke.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Louing? 'twere pitty I should be liuing else, beleeue me. Saue you, sir. Saue you, sweet ladie. Saue you, Monsieur ANAIDES. Saue you, deare Madame.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Do'st thou know him that saluted thee, HEDON?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: No, some idle FVNGOSO, that hath got aboue the cup-board, since yesterday.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: S'lud, I neuer saw him till this morning, and he salutes me as familiarly, as if we had knowne together, since the deluge, or the first yeere of Troy-action.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: A most right-handed, and auspicious encounter. Confine your selfe to your fortunes.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: For sports sake, let's haue some riddles, or purposes; hough.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: No faith, your prophecies are best, the t'other are stale.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Prophecies? we cannot all sit in at them; wee shall make a confusion. No; what calld you that we had in the fore-noone?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Substantiues, and Adiectiues. Ist not HEDON?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I, that, who begins?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I haue thought; speake your Adiectiues, sirs.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But doe not you change, then?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Not I, who saies?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Odoriferous.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Popular.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Humble.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: White-liuer'd.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Barbarous.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Pythagoricall.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Yours, Signior.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: What must I doe, sir?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Giue forth your Adiectiue, with the rest; as, prosperous, good, faire, sweet, well—

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Any thing, that hath not beene spoken.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Yes, sir: well-spoken, shall be mine.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What? ha' you all done?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Then the Substantiue is Breeches. Why odoriferous Breeches, Guardian?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Odoriferous, because odoriferous; that which containes most varietie of sauour, and smell, we say is most odoriferous: now, Breeches I presume are incident to that varietie, and therefore odoriferous Breeches.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Well, we must take it howsoeuer, who's next? PHILAVTIA.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Popular.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Why popular Breeches?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Mary, that is, when they are not content to be generally noted in court, but will presse forth on common stages, and brokers stalls, to the publique view of the world.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Good: why humble Breeches? ARGVRION.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Humble, because they vse to be sate vpon; besides, if you tie 'hem not vp, their propertie is to fall downe about your heeles.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Shee has worne the breeches, it seemes, which haue done so.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: But why white-liuer'd?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Why? 'shart, are not their linings white? besides, when they come in swaggering companie, and will pocket vp any thing, may they not properly be said to be white-liuer'd?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O, yes, wee must not denie it. And why barbarous, HE DON?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Barbarous, because commonly, when you haue worne your breeches sufficiently, you giue them to your Barber.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: That's good: but now Pythagoricall?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I, AMORPHVS. Why Pythagoricall Breeches?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: O, most kindly of all, 'tis a conceit of that fortune, I am bold to hug my braine for.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: How ist, exquisite AMORPHVS?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: O, I am rapt with it, 'tis so fit, so proper, so happy—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Nay, doe not racke vs thus?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I neuer truly relisht my selfe, before. Giue me your eares. Bree ches Pythagoricall, by reason of their transmigration, into seuerall shapes.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Most rare, in sweet troth. Mary, this young gentleman, for his well-spoken—

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I, why well-spoken Breeches?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Well-spoken? mary well-spoken, because— whatsoeuer they speake, is well taken; and whatsoeuer is well taken, is well-spoken.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Excellent! beleeue me.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Not so, ladies, neither.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: But why Breeches, now?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Breeches, quasi beare-riches; when a gallant beares all his ri ches in his breeches:

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Most fortunately etymologiz'd.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Nay, we haue another sport afore this, of A thing done, and Who did it, &c.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I, good PHANTASTE, let's haue that: Distribute the places.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Why, I imagine, A thing done; HEDON thinkes, Who did it; MORIA, With what it was done; ANAIDES, Where it was done; ARGVRION, When it was done; AMORPHVS, For what cause it was done; you PHILAVTIA, What followed vpon the doing of it; and this gentleman, Who would haue done it better. What? is't conceiu'd about?

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: The speake you, sir. Who would haue done it better?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: How! do's it beginne at me?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Yes, sir: This play is cal'd the Crab, it goes backward.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: May I not name my selfe?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: If you please, sir, and dare abide the venture of it.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Then, I would haue done it better, what euer it is.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: No doubt on't, sir: a good confidence. What followed vpon the act, PHILAVTIA?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: A few heate drops, and a moneths mirth.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: For what cause, AMORPHVS?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: For the delight of ladies.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: When, ARGVURION?

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Last progresse.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Where, ANAIDES?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Why, in a paire of pain'd slops.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: With what, MORIA?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: With a glyster.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who, HEDON?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: A trauailer.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Then, The thing done was, An oration was made. Rehearse. An oration was made.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: By a trauailer.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: With a glyster.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: In a paire of pain'd slops,

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Last progresse.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: For the delight of ladies.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: A few heat drops, and a moneths mirth followed.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: And, this silent gentleman would haue done it better.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: This was not so good, now.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: In good faith, these vnhappie pages would be whipt, for staying thus.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Beshrew my hand, and my heart, else.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I doe wonder at their protraction!

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Pray VENVS, my whore haue not discouer'd her selfe to the rascally hoyes, and that be the cause of their stay.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I must sute my selfe with another page: this idle PROSAITES will neuer be brought to wait well.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Sir, I haue a kinsman I could willingly wish to your seruice, if you would deigne to accept of him.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: And I shall bee glad (most sweet ladie) to imbrace him: where is hee?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: I can fetch him, sir, but I would bee loth to make you turne away your other page.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: You shall not, most sufficient ladie, I will keepe both: pray you lets goe see him.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Whither goes my loue?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Ile returne presently, I goe but to see a page, with this ladie.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: As sure as fate, 't is so; shee has opened all: A poxe of all cockatrices. Dam'me, if she haue plai'd loose with me, I'le cut her throat, within a haires breadth, so it may be heal'd againe.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: What, is he jealous of his Hermaphrodite?

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: O, I, this will be excellent sport.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: PHANTASTE! ARGVRION! what? you are sodainely strooke, me thinkes! for loues sake let's haue some musike, till they come. Ambition, reach the lyra, I pray you.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Any thing to which my Honour shall direct mee.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Come, AMORPHVS, cheare vp PHANTASTE.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: It shall bee my pride, faire ladie, to attempt all that is in my power. But here is an instrument that (alone) is able to infuse soule in the most melancholique, and dull disposde creature vpon earth. O! let mee kisse thy faire knees. Beauteous eares attend it.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Will you haue the Kisse, Honour?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I, good Ambition.
sp.l: O, That ioy so soone should waste!
or so sweet a blisse
as a kisse,
Might not for euer last!
So sugred, so melting, so soft, so delicious,
The dew that lyes on roses,
When the morne her selfe descloses,
is not so precious.
O, rather then I would it smother,
Were I to taste such another;
It should bee my wishing
That I might dye kissing.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: I made this dittie, and the note to it, vpon a kisse that my Honour gaue me; how like you it, sir?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: A prettie ayre, in generall, I like it well: but in particular, your long die-note did arride me most, but it was somwhat too long. I can shew one, almost of the same nature, but much before it and not so long, in a composition of mine owne. I thinke I haue both the note, and dittie about me.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Pray you, sir, see.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Yes, there is the note; and all the parts if I mis-thinke not. I will read the dittie to your beauties here, but first I am to make you familiar with the occasion, which presents it selfe thus. Vpon a time, going to take my leaue of the Emperour, and kisse his great hands; there being then present, the kings of France, and Arragon, the dukes of Sauoy, Florence, Orbeance, Bourbon, Brunswicke, the Lantgraue, Count Palatine, all which had seuerally feasted me; besides, infinite more of inferiour persons, as Counts and others it was my chance the Emperour detain'd by some exorbitant affaire) to wait him the fift part of an houre, or much neere it. In which time (retyring my selfe into a bay-window) the beauteous ladie ANNABELL, neece to the Empresse, and sister to the King of Arragon, who hauing neuer before eyde mee, (but only heard the common report of my vertue, learning, and trauaile) fell into that extremitie of passion, for my loue, that shee there immediately swouned: physicians were sent for, she had to her chamber, so to her bed; where (languishing some few daies) after many times calling vpon me, with my name in her lips, she expirde. As that (I must mourningly say) is the onely fault of my fortune, that, as it hath euer beene my hap to be sew'd to, by all ladies, and beauties, where I haue come, so, I neuer yet sojourn'd, or rested in that place, or part of the world, where some high-borne admirable faire feature died not for my loue.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: O, the sweet power of trauaile! are you guiltie of this, CVPID?

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: No, MERCVRIE, and that his page (COS) knowes, if he were here present to be sworne.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But, how doth this draw on the dittie, sir?

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: O, she is too quicke with him; he hath not deuis'd that yet.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Mary, some houre before she departed, she bequeath'd to mee this gloue; which golden legacie, the Emperour himselfe tooke care to send after me, in sixe coaches, couer'd all with blacke vellet, attended by the state of his empire; all which he freely presented mee with, and I reciprocally (out of the same bountie) gaue to the lords that brought it: only reseruing the gift of the deceas'd ladie, vpon which I composde this ode, and set it to my most affected instrument, the lyra.
sp.l: THou more then most sweet gloue,
Vnto my more sweet loue,
Suffer me to store with kisses
This emptie lodging, that now misses
The pure rosie hand, that ware thee,
Whiter then the kid, that bare thee.
Thou art soft, but that was softer;
CVPIDS selfe hath kist it ofter,
Then e're he did his mothers doues,
Supposing her the Queene of loues,
That was thy Mistresse,
Best of gloues.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Blasphemie, blasphemie, CVPID.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: I, I'le reuenge it time inough; HERMES.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Good AMORPHVS, let's heare it sing.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I care not to admit that, since it pleaseth PHILAVTIA to request it.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Heere, sir.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: After he hath sung. Nay, play it, I pray you, you doe well, you doe well— How like you it, sir?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Verie well in troth.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: But very well? O, you are a meere mammothrept in judgement then. Why, doe you not obserue how excellently the dittie is affected in euerie place? that I doe not marrie a word of short quantitie to a long note? nor an ascending sillable to a descending tone? Besides, vpon the word (best) there, you see how I doe enter with an odde minnum, and driue it thorow the briefe, which no intelligent Musician (I know) but wil affirme to be verie rare, extraordinarie, and pleasing.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: And yet not fit to lament the death of a ladie, for all this.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Tut, heere be they will swallow any thing.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Pray you let me haue a coppie of it, AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And me too, in troth, I like it exceedingly.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I haue denied it to princes, neuerthelesse to you (the true female twinnes of perfection) I am wonne, to depart withall.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: I hope I shall haue my Honours coppie.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Who is return'd from seeking his page. You are ambitious in that, HEDON.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: How now, ANAIDES! what is it hath conjur'd vp this distemperature in the circle of your face?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: S'lood, what haue you to doe? A pox vpon your filthie trauailing face, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Nay, doo'st heare, mischiefe?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Away, muske-cat.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I say to thee, thou art rude, debauch't, impudent, coorse, impolisht, a frapler, and base.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Heart of my father, what a strange alteration has halfe a yeeres haunting of ordinaries wrought in this fellow! that came with a tuff-taffeta ierkin to towne but the other day, and a paire of penilesse hose, and now he is turn'd HERCVLES, he wants but a club.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Sir, you with the pencill on your chinne; I will garter my hose with your guts, and that shall be all.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: S'lid, what rare fireworkes be heere? flash, flash.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What's the matter HEDON? can you tell?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Nothing, but that hee lackes crownes, and thinkes weele lend him some, to be friends.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Come, Asotus returnes with Moria, and Morus. sweet ladie, in good truth I'le haue it, you shall not denie me. MORVS, perswade your aunt I may haue her picture, by any meanes.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Yes, sir: good aunt now, let him haue it, hee will vse mee the better, if you loue me, doe, good aunt.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Well, tell him, he shall haue it.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Master, you shall haue it, she saies.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Shall I? thanke her, good page.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: What, has he entertain'd the foole?

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: I, heele wait close, you shall see, though the begger hang off, awhile.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Aunt, my master thankes you.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Call him hither.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Yes, master

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Yes, in veritie, and gaue me this pursse, and he has promis'd me a most fine dogge; which he will haue drawne, with my picture, he saies: and desires most vehemently to bee knowne to your ladiships.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Call him hither, 'tis good groping such a gull.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Master ASOTVS, master ASOTVS.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: For loues sake, let me goe: you see, I am call'd to the ladies.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Wilt thou forsake me then?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: God so, what would you haue me doe?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Come hither, master ASOTVS. I doe ensure your ladiships, he is a gentleman of a verie worthie desert: and of a most bountifull nature. You must shew and insinuate your selfe responsible, and equiualent now to my commendment. Good Honors, grace him.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I protest (more then most faire ladies) I doe wish all varietie of diuine pleasures, choice sports, sweet musique, rich fare, braue attire, soft beds, and silken thoughts attend these faire beauties. Will it please your ladiship to weare this chaine of pearle, and this diamond, for my sake?

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: And you, Madame, this iewell, and pendants.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Wee know not how to deserue these bounties, out of so slight merit, ASOTVS.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: No, in faith, but there's my gloue for a fauour.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: And soone, after the reuells, I will bestow a garter on you.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: O Lord, ladies! it is more grace then euer I could haue hop'd, but that it pleaseth your ladiships to extend. I protest, it is enough, that you but take knowledge of my— if your ladiships want embroidered gownes, tires of any fashion, rebatu's, iewells, or carkanets, any thing whatsoeuer, if you vouchsafe to accept.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: And for it, they will helpe you to shooe-ties, and deuices.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I cannot vtter my selfe (deare beauties) but, you can conceiue—

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Sir, we will acknowledge your seruice, doubt not: henceforth, you shall bee no more ASOTVS to vs, but our gold-finch, and wee your cages.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: O VENVS, Madams! how shall I deserue this? if I were but made acquainted with HEDON, now, I'le trie: pray you away.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: How he praies Money to goe away from him!

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: AMORPHVS, a word with you: here's a watch I would bestow vpon you, pray you make me knowne to that gallant.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: That I will, sir. Monsieur HEDON, I must intreat you to exchange knowledge with this gentleman.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: 'Tis a thing (next to the water we expect) I thirst after, sir. Good Monsieur ASOTVS.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Good Monsieur HEDON, I would be glad to be lou'd of men of your ranke, and spirit, I protest. Please you to accept this paire of bracelets, sir: they are not worth the bestowing—

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: O, HERCVLES, how the gentleman purchases! this must needes bring ARGVRION to a consumption.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Sir, I shall neuer stand in the merit of such bountie, I feare.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: O, VENVS, sir; your acquaintance shall bee sufficient. And if at any time you neede my bill, or my bond.

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Argurion swounes. O, Ô.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Helpe the ladie there.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Gods deare, ARGVRION! Madame, how doe you?

sp.speaker: ARG.
sp.p: Sicke.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Haue her forth, and giue her aire.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I come againe strait, ladies.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Well, I doubt, all the physique hee has will scarce recouer her: shee's too farre spent.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene IIII.
div.stage: PHILAVTIA, GELAIA, ANAIDES, COS, PROSAITES, PHANTASTE, MORIA, AMORPHVS, HEDON.

sp.p: O Here's the water come: fetch glasses, page.

sp.speaker: GEL.
sp.p: Heart of my body, here's a coile indeed, with your iealous humours. Nothing but whore, and bitch, and all the villanous swaggering names you can thinke on? S'lid, take your bottle, and put it in your guts for me, I'le see you poxt ere I follow you any longer.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nay, good punke, sweete rascall; dam' mee, if I am iealous now.

sp.speaker: GEL.
sp.p: That's true indeede: pray let's goe.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: What's the matter, there?

sp.speaker: GEL.
sp.p: S'light, he has mee vpon intergatories, (nay, my mother shall know how you vse me) where I haue beene? and, why I should stay so long? and, how ist possible? and withall, calls me at his pleasure, I know not how many cockatrices, and things.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: In truth and sadnesse, these are no good epitaphs, ANAIDES, to bestow vpon any gentlewoman; and (Ile ensure you) if I had knowne you would haue dealt thus with my daughter, she should neuer haue fancied you so deeply, as shee has done. Goe too.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Why, doe you heare, mother MORIA. Heart!

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you, sir, doe not sweare.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Sweare? why? S'lood, I haue sworne afore now, I hope. Both you and your daughter mistake me. I haue not honor'd ARETE, that is held the worthiest ladie in court (next to CYNTHIA) with halfe that obseruance, and respect, as I haue done her in priuate, howsoeuer outwardly I haue carried my selfe carelesse, and negligent. Come, you are a foolish, punke, and know not when you are well imploi'd. Kisse me, come on. Doe it, I say.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Nay, indeed I must confesse, shee is apt to misprision. But I must haue you leaue it, minion.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: How now, ASOTVS? how do's the ladie?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Faith, ill. I haue left my page with her, at her lodging.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: O, here's the rarest water that euer was tasted: fill him some.

sp.speaker: PRO.
sp.p: What! has my master a new page?

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Yes, a kinsman of the ladie MORIAS: you must waite better now, or you are casheer'd, PROSAITES.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Come, gallants, you must pardon my foolish humour: when I am angrie, that any thing crosses mee, I grow impatient straight. Here, I drinke to you.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O, that we had fiue, or sixe bottles more of this liquor.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Now I commend your iudgement, AMORPHVS, who's that knockes? Looke, page.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: O, most delicious, a little of this would make ARGVRION well.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O, no, giue her no cold drinke, by any meanes.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: S'lood, this water is the spirit of wine, I'le be hang'd else.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Here's the ladie ARETE, Madame.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene V.
div.stage: ARETE, MORIA, PHANTASTE, PHILAVTIA, ANAIDES, GELAIA, COS, PROSAITES, AMORPHVS, ASOTVS, HEDON, MERCVRIE, CVPID.

sp.p: WHat! at your beuer, gallants?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Wilt please your ladiship drinke? tis of the new fountayne water.

sp.speaker: ARE.
sp.p: Not I, MORIA, I thanke you. Gallants, you are for this night free, to your peculiar delights; CYNTHIA will haue no sports: when shee is pleas'd to come forth, you shall haue knowledge. In the meane time, I could wish you did prouide for solemne reuels, and some vnlook't-for deuice of wit, to entertaine her, against she should vouchsafe to grace your pastimes with her presence.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: What say you to a Masque?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Nothing better, if the proiect were new, and rare.

sp.speaker: ARE.
sp.p: Why, Ile send for CRITES, and haue his aduice; be you ready in your indeauours: He shall discharge you of the inuentiue part.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: But, will not your ladiship stay?

sp.speaker: ARE.
sp.p: Not now, PHANTASTE.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Let her goe, I pray you, good ladie Sobrietie, I am glad wee are rid of her.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What a set face the gentlewoman has, as shee were still going to a sacrifice?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O, shee is the extraction of a dozen of Puritans, for a looke.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Of all Nymphs i' the court, I cannot away with her; 'tis the coursest thing—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I wonder, how CYNTHIA can affect her so aboue the rest! Here be they are euery way as faire as shee, and a thought fairer, I trow.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: I, and as ingenious, and conceited as shee.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: I, and as politique as shee, for all shee sets such a fore-head on't.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Would I were dead, if I would change to be CYNTHIA.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p:
And there's her minion CRITES! why his aduice more then AMORPHVS? haue not I inuention, afore him? Learning, to better that
inuention, aboue him? and infanted, with pleasant trauaile—

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Death, what talke you of his learning? he vnderstands no more then a schoole-boy; I haue put him downe my selfe a thousand times (by this aire) and yet I neuer talkt with him but twice, in my life: you neuer saw his like. I could neuer get him to argue with me, but once, and then, because I could not construe an Author I quoted at first sight, hee went away, and laught at me. By HERCVLES, I scorne him, as I doe the sod den Nymph, that was here e'en now, his mistris ARETE: And I loue my selfe for nothing else.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: I wonder the fellow do's not hang himselfe, being thus scorn'd, and contemn'd of vs that are held the most accomplisht societie of gallants!

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: By your selues, none else.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: I protest, if I had no musique in me, no courtship, that I were not a reueller and could dance, or had not those excellent qualities that giue a man life, and perfection, but a meere poore scholer as he is, I thinke I should make some desperate way with my selfe, whereas now (would I might neuer breathe more) if I doe know that creature in the kingdome, with whom I would change.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: This is excellent: well, I must alter all this soone.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Looke you doe, CVPID. The bottles haue wrought, it seemes.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: O, I am sorry the reuels are crost. I should ha' tickled it soone. I did neuer appeare till then. S'lid, I am the neatlyest-made gallant i' the companie, and haue the best presence; and my dancing— well, I know what our vsher said to me, lasst time I was at the schoole: would I might haue lead PHILAVTIA in the measures, and it had beene the gods will. I am most worthy, I am sure.

sp.speaker: MORVS.
sp.p: Master, I can tell you newes, the ladie kist mee yonder, and plaid with me, and sayes shee lou'd you once, as well as shee do's me, but that you cast her off.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Peace, my most esteemed page.

sp.speaker: MORVS.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: What lucke is this, that our reuels are dasht? Now was I be ginning to glister, i' the very high way of preferment. And CYNTHIA had but seene me dance a straine, or doe but one trick, I had beene kept in court, I should neuer haue needed to looke towards my friends againe.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Containe your selfe. You were a fortunate yong man, if you knew your owne good: which I haue now proiected, and will presently multiply vpon you. Beauties, and Valors, your vouchsaf'd applause to a motion. the humorous CYNTHIA hath, for this night, with-drawne the light of your de-light—

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Tis true AMORPHVS, what may we doe to redeeme it?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p:
Redeeme that we cannot, but, to create a new flame, is in our power. Here is a gentleman my scholer, whom (for some priuate reasons me specially mouing) I am couetous to gratifie with title of Master, in
the noble, and subtile science of Courtship: For which grace, he shall this night in court, and in the long gallery, hold his publique Act, by open challenge, to all Masters of the mysterie whatsoeuer, to play at the foure choice, and principall weapons thereof, viz. the bare Accost, the better Regard, the solemne Addresse, and the perfect Close. What say you?

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Excellent, excellent, AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Well, let vs then take our time by the fore-head: I will instantly haue bills drawne, and aduanc'd in euery angle of the court. Sir, betray not your too much ioy. ANAIDES, wee must mixe this gentleman with you in acquaintance, Monsieur ASOTVS.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: I am easily intreated to grace any of your friends, AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Sir, and his friends shall likewise grace you, sir. Nay, I begin to know my selfe, now.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: O, you must continue your bounties.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Must I? why, I'le giue him this ruby on my finger. Doe you heare, sir? I doe heartily with your acquaintance, and I partly know my selfe worthy of it; please you, sir, to accept this poore ruby, in a ring, sir. The poesie is of my owne deuice. Let this blush for me, sir.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: So it must for me, too. For I am not asham'd to take it.

sp.speaker: MORVS.
sp.p: Sweet man! by my troth, master, I loue you, will you loue me, too? for my aunts sake? Ile waite well, you shall see. Ile still bee here. Would I might neuer stirre, but you are a fine man in these clothes, Master, shall I haue 'hem, when you haue done with them?

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: As for that, MORVS, thou shalt see more hereafter: in the meane time, by this aire, or by this feather, Ile doe as much for thee, as any gallant shall doe for his page, whatsoeuer, in this court, corner of the world, or kingdome.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: I wonder, this gentleman should affect to keepe a foole! mee thinkes, he makes sport enough with himselfe.

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Well, PROSAITES, 'twere good you did waite closer.

sp.speaker: PRO.
sp.p: I, Ile looke to it; 'tis time.

sp.speaker: COS.
sp.p: The reuels would haue beene most sumptuous to night, if they had gone forward.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: They must needs, when al the choisest singularities of the court were vp in pantofles; ne're a one of them, but was able to make a whole shew of it selfe.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Within. Sirrah, a torch, a torch.

sp.speaker: PRO.
sp.p: O, what a call is there! I will haue a canzonet made, with nothing in it, but sirrah; and the burthen shall be, I come.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: How now, CVPID, how doe you like this change?

sp.speaker: CVP.
sp.p: Faith, the thred of my deuice is crackt, I may goe sleepe till the reuelling musique awake me.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p:
And ther too, CVPID, without you had preuented the Fountayne. Alas, poore god, that remembers not selfe-Loue, to bee proofe
against the violence of his quiuer! Well, I haue a plot vpon these prizers, for which, I must presently find out CRITES, and with his assistance, pursue it to a high straine of laughter, or MERCVRIE hath lost of his mettall.

sp.l: IT is resolu'd on, CRITES, you must doe it.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: The grace diuinest MERCVRIE hath done me,
In this vouchsafde discouerie of himselfe,
Binds my obseruance in the vtmost terme
Of satisfaction, to his godly will:
Though I professe (without the affectation)
Of an enforc'd, and form'd austeritie)
I could be willing to enioy no place
With so vnequall natures.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.l: We beleeue it.
But for our sake, and to inflict iust paines
On their prodigious follies, aide vs now:
No man is, presently, made bad, with ill.
And good men, like the sea, should still maintaine
Their noble taste, in midst of all fresh humours,
That flow about them, to corrupt their streames,
Bearing no season, much lesse salt of goodnesse.
It is our purpose, CRITES, to correct,
And punish, with our laughter, this nights sport
Which our court-Dors so heartily intend:
And by that worthy scorne, to make them know
How farre beneath the dignitie of man
Their serious, and most practis'd actions are.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: I, but though MERCVRIE can warrant out
His vnder-takings, and make all things good,
Out of the powers of his diuinitie,
Th'offence will be return'd with weight on me,
That am a creature so despisde, and poore;
When the whole Court shall take it selfe abusde
By our ironicall confederacie.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.l: You are deceiu'd. The better race in court
That haue the true nobilitie, call'd vertue,
Will apprehend it, as a gratefull right
Done to their separate merit: and approue
The fit rebuke of so ridiculous heads,
Who with their apish customes, and forc'd garbes,
Would bring the name of courtier in contempt,
Did it not liue vnblemisht in some few,
Whom equall IOVE hath lou'd, and PHOEBVS form'd
Of better mettall, and in better mould.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Well, since my leader on is MERCVRIE,
I shall not feare to follow. If I fall,
My proper vertue shall be my reliefe,
That follow'd such a cause, and such a chiefe.

sp.p: NO more, if you loue mee, good master, you are incompatible to liue withall: Send mee for the ladies.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Nay, but intend me.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Feare me not, I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Render not your selfe a refractarie, on the sodaine. I can allow well, you should repute highly, heartily (and to the most) of your own endowments; it giues you forth to the world the more assur'd: but with reseruation of an eye, to be alwaies turn'd dutifully back vpon your teacher.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Nay, good, sir, leaue it to mee. Trust mee with trussing all the points of this action, I pray. S'lid, I hope we shall find wit to performe the science, as well as another.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I confesse you to be of an aped, and docible humour. Yet, there are certaine puntilioes, or (as I may more nakedly insinuate them) certaine intrinsecate strokes, and wardes, to which your actiuitie is not yet amounted. As your gentile dor, in colours. For supposition, your mistris appeares heere in prize, ribbanded with greene, and yellow; now it is the part of euery obsequious seruant, to be sure to haue daily about him copie, and varietie of colours, to be presently answerable to any hourely, or half-hourely change in his mistris reuolution.—

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: (I know it, sir.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Giue leaue, I pray you) which if your Antagonist, or player-against-you shall ignorantly be without, and your selfe can produce; you giue him the dor.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I, I, sir.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Or, if you can possesse your opposite, that the greene your mistris weares, is her reioycing or exultation in his seruice; the yellow, suspicion of his truth, (from her height of affection:) and that he (greenly credulous) shall withdraw thus, in priuate, and from the aboundance of his pocket (to displace her jelous conceit) steale into his hat the colour, whose bluenesse doth expresse truenesse, (shee being nor so, nor so affected) you giue him the dor.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Doe not I know it, sir?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Nay, good— swell not aboue your vnderstanding. There is yet a third dor, in colours.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: I know it too, I know it.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Doe you know it too? what is it? Make good your knowledge.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Why it is— no matter for that.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Doe it, on poene of the dor.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Why? what is't, say you?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Loe, you haue giuen your selfe the dor. But I will remonstrate to you the third dor; which is not, as the two former dors, indicatiue, but deliberatiue: As how? As thus. Your Riualis, with a dutifull, and serious care, lying in his bed, meditating how to obserue his mistris, dispatcheth his lacquay to the chamber, early, to know what her colours are for the day; with purpose to apply his weare that day, accordingly: You lay wait before, preoccupie the chamber-maide, corrupt her, to returne false colours; He followes the fallacie; comes out accoutred to his beleeu'd instructions; your mistresse smiles; and you giue him the dor.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Why, so I told you, sir, I knew it.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Tolde mee? It is a strange outrecuidance! your humour too much redoundeth.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Why, sir, what, doe you thinke you know more?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I know that a cooke may as soone, and properly be said to smel wel, as you to be wise. I know these are most cleere, and cleane strokes. But then, you haue your passages, and imbroccata's in courtship; as the bitter Rob in wit; the Reuerse in face, or wry-mouth; and these more subtle, and secure offenders. I will example vnto you. Your opponent makes entrie, as you are ingag'd with your mistresse. You seeing him, close in her eare, with this whisper (here comes your Babion, disgrace him) and withall, stepping off, fall on his bosome, and turning to her, politiquely, aloud say, ladie, reguard this noble gentleman, a man rarely parted, second to none in this court; and then, stooping ouer his shoulder, your hand on his brest, your mouth on his back-side, you giue him the Reuerse stroke, with this Sanna, or Storkes-bill, which makes vp your wits Bob, most bitter.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Nay, for heauens sake, teach me no more. I know all as well— S'lid, if I did not, why was I nominated? why did you chuse mee? why did the ladies pricke out mee? I am sure there were other gallants. But me of all the rest? By that light, and as I am a courtier, would I might neuer stirre, but 'tis strange. Would to the lord, the ladies would come once.

div.head: Act V. Scene III.
div.stage: MORPHIDES, AMORPHVS, ASOTVS, HEDON, ANAIDES, THE THRONG. LADIES, CITIZEN, WIFE, PAGES, TAYLOR, MERCER, PERFVMER, IEWELLER, &c.

sp.p: SIgnior, the gallants and ladies are at hand. Are you readie, sir?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Instantly. Goe, accomplish your attire: Cousin MORPHIDES, assist me, to make good the doore with your officious tyrannie.

sp.speaker: CIT.
sp.p: By your leaue my masters there, pray you let's come by.

sp.speaker: PAG.
sp.p: You by? why should you come by, more then we?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Why, sir? Because he is my brother, that playes the prizes.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Your brother?

sp.speaker: CIT.
sp.p: I, her brother, sir, and we must come in.

sp.speaker: TAY.
sp.p: Why, what are you?

sp.speaker: CIT.
sp.p: I am her husband, sir.

sp.speaker: TAY.
sp.p: Then thrust forward your head.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: What tumult is there?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Who's there? beare backe there. Stand from the doore.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Enter none but the ladies, and their hang-bies; welcome Beauties, and your kind Shadowes.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: This countrie ladie, my friend, good signior AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: And my cockatrice, heere.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: She is welcome.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Knocke those same pages there; and goodman Cockescombe the cittizen, who would you speake withall?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: With whom? your brother?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Who is your brother?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Master ASOTVS? Is hee your brother? Hee is taken vp with great persons. Hee is not to know you to night.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: O IOVE, master! and there come ere a cittizen gentlewoman in my name, let her haue entrance, I pray you. It is my sister.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: CIT.
sp.p: Brother, master ASOTVS.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: 'Tis I, brother.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Gods me! There she is, good master, intrude he.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: Make place. Beare backe there.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Knocke that simple fellow, there.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Nay, good sir; It is my husband.

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: The simpler fellow hee. Away, backe with your head, sir.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Brother, you must pardon your non-entry: Husbands are not allow'd here in truth. Ile come home soone with my sister; pray you meet vs with a lanthorn, brother. Be merrie, sister: I shall make you laugh anon.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Your prizer is not readie AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Apprehend your places, hee shall be soone; and at all points.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Is there any body come to answer him? Shal we haue any sport.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Sport of importance; howsoeuer, giue me the gloues.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Gloues! why gloues, Signior?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: He distributes gloues. What's the ceremonie?

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Besides their receiu'd fitnesse, at all prizes, they are here properly accommodate to the nuptials of my schollers hauiour to the ladie courtship. Please you apparell your hands. Madam PHANTASTE, madam PHILAVTIA, Guardian, Signior HEDON, Signior ANAIDES, Gentlemen all, Ladies.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Thankes, good AMORPHVS.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I will now call forth my prouost, and present him.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Heart! why should not we be masters, aswell as he?

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: That's true, and play our masters prizes, as well as the t'other?

sp.speaker: MOR.
sp.p: In sadnesse, for vsing your court-weapons, me thinks, you may.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Nay, but why should not wee ladies play our prizes, I pray? I see no reason, but we should take 'hem downe, at their owne weapons.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Troth, and so we may, if we handle 'hem well.

sp.speaker: WIF.
sp.p: I indeed, forsooth, Madame, if 'twere i' the citie, wee would thinke foule scorne, but we would, forsooth.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Pray you, what shoul'd we call your name?

sp.speaker: WIF.
sp.p: My name is, Downefall.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Good mistris Downefall! I am sorry, your husband could not get in.

sp.speaker: WIF.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for him, sir.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: No, no, shee has the more liberty for her selfe.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Peace, A flourish. peace: They come.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: So. Keepe vp your ruffe: the tincture of your necke is not all so pure, but it will aske it. Maintayne your sprig vpright; your cloke on your halfe-shoulder falling; So: I will reade your bill, aduance it, and present you. Silence.

div.p: Be it knowne to all that professe courtship, The challenge by these presents (from the white sattin reueller, to the cloth of tissue, and bodkin) that we, VLYSSES-POLYTROPVS-AMORPHVS, Master of the noble, and subtile science of courtship, doe giue leaue and licence to our Prouost, ACOLASTVS-POLYPRAGMON-ASOTVS, to play his Masters prize, against all Masters whatsoeuer in this subtile mysterie, at these foure, the choice, and most cunning weapons of court-complement, viz. the bare Accost; the better Reguard; the solemne Addresse; and the perfect Close. These are therefore to giue notice, to all commers, that hee, she said ACOLASTVS-POLYPRAGMON-ASOTVS, is here present (by the helpe of his Mercer, Taylor, Millaner, Sempster, and so forth) at his designed houre, in this faire gallery, the present day of this present moneth, to performe, and doe his vttermost for the atchieuement, and bearing away of the prizes, which are these: viz. for the bare Accost, two Wall-eyes, in a face forced: For the better Reguard, a Face fauourably simpring, with a Farme wauing: For the solemne Addresse, two Lips wagging, and neuer a wise word: For the perfect Close, a Wring by the hand, with a Banquet in a corner. And PHOEBVS saue CYNTHIA.

sp.p: Appeareth no man yet, to answere the prizer? No voice? Musique, giue them their summons. Musique sounds.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: The solemnity of this is excellent.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Silence. Well, I perceiue your name is their terror; and keepeth them backe.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p:
I faith, Master, Let's goe: no body comes. Victus, victa,
victum; Victi, victae, victi— Let's bee retrograde.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Stay. That were dispunct to the ladies. Rather, our selfe shall be your Encounter. Take your state, vp, to the wall: And, ladie, may we implore you to stand forth, as first terme, or bound to our courtship.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: A charge. 'Fore heauen, 'twill shew rarely.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Sound a charge.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: A poxe on't. Your vulgar will count this fabulous, and impudent, now: by that candle, they'le ne're conceit it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Excellent well! Admirable!

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: They act their accost seuerally to the lady that stands forth. Most fashionably, beleeue it.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: O, he is a well-spoken gentleman.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Now the other.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: For a Scholer, Honor.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: O, 'tis too dutch. He reeles too much.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: A flourish. This weapon is done.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: No, we haue our two bouts, at euery weapon, expect.
WHere be these gallants, and their braue prizer here?

sp.speaker: MORP.
sp.p: Who's there? beare backe: Keepe the dore.

sp.speaker: AMOR.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIT.
sp.p: By your licence, grand-master. Come forward, sir.

sp.speaker: ANAI.
sp.p: Heart! who let in that rag there, amongst vs? put him out, an impecunious creature.

sp.speaker: HEDO.
sp.p: Out with him.

sp.speaker: MORP.
sp.p: Come, sir.

sp.speaker: AMOR.
sp.p: You must be retrograde.

sp.speaker: CRIT.
sp.p: Soft, sir, I am Truchman, and doe flourish before this Monsieur, or french-behau'd gentleman, here; who is drawne hither by report of your chartells, aduanced in court, to proue his fortune with your prizer, so he may haue faire play shewne him, and the libertie to choose his stickler.

sp.speaker: AMOR.
sp.p: Is he a Master?

sp.speaker: CRIT.
sp.p: That, sir, he has to shew here; and, confirmed vnder the hands of the most skilfull, and cunning complementaries aliue: please you reade, sir.

sp.speaker: AMOR.
sp.p: What shall we doe?

sp.speaker: ANAI.
sp.p: Death, disgrace this fellow i' the blacke-stuffe, what euer you doe.

sp.speaker: AMOR.
sp.p: Why, but he comes with the stranger.

sp.speaker: HEDO.
sp.p: That's no matter. He is our owne countryman.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: I, and he is a scholer besides. You may disgrace him here, with authoritie.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Well, see these first.

sp.speaker: ASO.
sp.p: Now shall I be obseru'd by yon'd scholer, till I sweat againe; I would to IOVE, it were ouer.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.p: Sir, this is the wight of worth, that dares you to the encounter. A gentleman of so pleasing, and ridiculous a carriage; as, euen standing, carries meat in the mouth, you see; and I assure you, although no bred courtling, yet a most particular man, of goodly hauings, well fashion'd hauiour, and of as hard'ned, and excellent a barke, as the most naturally-qualified amongst them, inform'd, reform'd, and transform'd, from his originall citticisme, by this elixi'r, or meere magazine of man. And, for your spectators, you behold them, what they are: The most choice particulars in court: This tels tales well; This prouides coaches; This repeates iests; This presents gifts; This holds vp the arras; This takes downe from horse; This protests by this light; This sweares by that candle; This delighteth; This adoreth. Yet, all but three men. Then for your ladies, the most proud wittie creatures, all things apprehending, nothing vnderstanding, perpetually laughing, curious maintayners of fooles, mercers, and minstrels, costly to be kept, miserably keeping, all disdayning, but their painter, and pothecary, twixt whom and them there is this reciprock commerce, their beauties maintaine their painters, and their painters their beauties.

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.p: Sir, you haue plaid the painter your selfe, and limb'd them to the life. I desire to deserue before 'hem.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: This is authentique. Hauing read the certificate. Wee must resolue to entertaine the Monsieur, howsoeuer we neglect him.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Come, let's all goe together, and salute him.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Content, and not looke o' the other.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Well deuis'd: and a most punishing disgrace.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: On.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Monsieur. We must not so much betray our selues to discourtship, as to suffer you to be longer vnsaluted: Please you to vse the state, ordain'd for the opponent; in which nature, without enuy we receiue you.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: And embrace you.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: And commend vs to you, sir.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Beleeue it, he is a man of excellent silence.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: He keepes all his wit for action.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: This hath discountenanc'd our scholaris, most richly.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Out of all emphasis. The Monsieur sees, we regard him not.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Hold on: make it knowne how bitter a thing it is, not to bee look't on in court.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: S'lud, will he call him to him yet? doe's not Monsieur perceiue our disgrace?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Hart! he is a foole, I see. Wee haue done our selues wrong to grace him.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: S'light, what an asse was I, to embrace him?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.p: Illustrous, and fearefull iudges—

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Turne away, turne away.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.p: It is the sute of the strange opponent (to whom you ought not to turne your tailes, and whose noses I must follow) that he may haue the iustice, before hee encounter his respected aduersarie, to see some light stroke of his play, commenc'd with some other.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: Answere not him, but the stranger, we will not beleeue him.

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: I will demand him my selfe.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.p: O dreadfull disgrace, if a man were so foolish to feele it!

sp.speaker: AMO.
sp.p: Is it your sute, Monsieur, to see some praelude of my scholer? Now, sure the Monsieur wants language.

sp.speaker: HED.
sp.p: And take vpon him to be one of the accomplisht? S'light, that's a goodiest: would we could take him with that nullitie. Non sapette voi parlar' Itagliano?

sp.speaker: ANA.
